Posts.Content: I had the Da Vinci surgery June 3rd, my hormone therapy started July 3rd and I had 38 salvage radiation treatments that I completed on November 12th. I will be on the hormone therapy (Lupron) for 2 years as a safety precaution since I had stage 4 cancer with metastatic disease. My last PSA test was 0.00 so I am a member of the Zero Club right now and I hope I stay that way.

Posts.Content: I am also experiencing bowel issues that began in my third week of treatments. I am set to receive treatment number 32 of 38 this afternoon and have been using Imodium AD and I have made changes to my diet to help with the bowel issues. I am really glad that I will finish up my treatments on November 12th so my bowels can return back to normal.

Posts.Title: Bowel issues with SRT

Posts.Content: I had my PSA Test on December 30 hit my first milestone, it has been 7 months since my Da Vinci surgery and I am still a member of the Zero Club. Next PSA test is March 30th. This is awesome news for me as my post op biopsy revealed stage 4 cancer with a Gleason score of 9 and Metastatic Disease. I had my second Lupron shot after that test and I have my 3rd Lupron shot June 30th and my last Lupron shot December 3oth. I just hope that the good news keeps coming as I am scheduled to have PSA checks every 90 days moving forward.

Posts.Title: Metformin

Posts.Content: I am a diabetic and currently take Metformin and I was taking it during my salvage radiation treatments and I was also on Lupron at the same time. I am not sure about my personal results yet. Due to the aggressiveness of my prostate cancer (G9)with Metastatic Disease, my medical team is throwing all options at me. Next Tuesday I will start Chemotherapy as a proactive approach due to Metastasis and because they found Lung Nodules in my CT scan. Unfortunately the Lung Nodules are too small to biopsy or to be picked up on a PET Scan.

Posts.Title: Metformin

Posts.Content: I figured I would check back in since I have not been online much lately. I've had 4 of my 6 chemotherapy treatments (Docetaxel) and they have been rough. I was hospitalized after the first treatment because my insurance company refused to allow me to receive Nuelasta after the treatment. I got so ill I had to be brought to the hospital and was admitted for 3 days. My WBC was in the danger zone as were my platelets so I was treated over the next three days and released. Each treatment has been brutal as far as getting sick and my body getting weak and pain levels increasing with each treatment. My insurance company began approving Neulasta after the second chemotherapy treatment as they were threatened with a lawsuit if they refused the shot a second time. I had a Eleguard shot days before my 4th treatment and it compounded the symptoms of fatigue, nausea and pain, that really made me feel at my lowest point. I have continued working in between chemotherapy treatments as I feel up to it. I usually feel good enough toward the end of the second week to go back to work for 6 or 7 days prior to the next treatment. I have two more treatments to go, July 28th and August 18th. I will then be scheduled for another CT Scan to check my lungs to see what the status is of the nodules. Over all the worst part of this is that my whole body feels really weak, I have no strength what so ever. My oncologist has informed me that I will be this way until all of the drugs are out of my system. However the good news is I am still here fighting and I know I have given myself every opportunity possible to battle the cancer and hopefully win the fight. I've had Da Vinci Surgery, 38 Radiation Treatments, 2 Lupron injections (6 month dose), 1 Eleguard injection (6 month dose) and 6 doses of Docetaxel when the chemo is complete. I will stay on Eleguard through 2017 with my last dose in December 2017. After that it is active surveillance and a lot of praying that the cancer does not come back. My last PSA came back as undetectable on June 29th so things are looking good so far.

Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: I am currently receiving Lupron injections (once every 6 moths) and my Medical Oncologist is suggesting that I start on Docetaxel in two weeks (6 treatments)to improve my chances of a longer life expectency. The available studies for this only show an increased life expectency between 13 and 17 months for patients my age. Is anyone here receiving Chemo (Docetaxel) while on ADT? If so, what side effects have you been experiencing? What can I expect? I am already experiencing bone, muscle, joint and abdominal pain as well as fatigue, nausea and hot flashes. Thanks for any feedback you can provide.

Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Per my Medical Oncologist recommendation, I am starting Chemotherapy tomorrow due to the aggressiveness of my cancer. Since the cancer got into my lymph nodes he does not want to wait for my PSA to rise, my recent CAT Scan found two Lung nodules that could be cancerous, however they are too small to biopsy or do a PET Scan on. For that reason I am following the Medical Oncologists advice and starting Chemotherapy. I am not sure how my body will respond, I had a real rough time with radiation last fall and hope the Chemotherapy will not be much worse than radiation so I can attempt to go to work while under treatment. I just filled out my FMLA paperwork as a precaution to missing any work due to illness from treatments.

Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: The hormone therapy stops the body from producing testosterone which in turn starves the cancer cells. The radiation may not have killed all of the cancer cells and adding hormone therapy to the treatments provide the patient with a best chance to eliminate the cancer cells. I received 38 radiation treatments and I have been receiving hormone therapy for 9 months and it will continue for a total of 3 years.

Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Great update, as for the incontinence, it can take time to get back to normal. It took me almost four months to get past the incontinence issue. Don't get frustrated, you can get over that, it just takes time and patience.
Posts.Title: Six-week post-op progress report

Posts.Content: I met with both my Urologist and my Radiological Oncologist over the last couple of weeks and they both want me to consider adding Chemotherapy to my treatments. They both quoted studies that say Hormone Therapy and Chemotherapy when given together provide stage 4 prostate cancer patients with Metastasis the best chance to extend life expectancy. Currently the hormone therapy side effects have been brutal, I have bone, joint and muscle pain as well as nausea, abdominal pain, diarrhea, hot flashes, chills and fatigue. I believe the first chemo drug that I will be given is docetaxel, combined with the steroid drug prednisone. What side effects can I expect to add once the Chemotherapy begins?

Posts.Title: Celebration day today!

Posts.Content: Jack, I had surgery and my Gleason was a 9. My Urologist wanted me to do radiation rather than surgery but I chose not to follow that advice. I ended up having my prostate, the seminal vesicle, a nerve bundle and 11 lymph nodes removed, after surgery I was informed of the positive margin. Since surgery on June 3rd 2015 I have had 3 hormone therapy shots with a 4th one scheduled for the end of December, I have also had 38 radiation treatments and 8 chemotherapy treatments. My current PSA level is undetectable. is the catheter a PIA? Absolutely, but you need to look at the big picture, long term survival. Do I have any regrets? I do not have any regrets and I am happy I made my own decisions because I feel removing as much cancer as possible gave me the best chance at long term survival.

Posts.Title: Higher grade gleason - analysis/opinion

Posts.Content: Thank you for the responses, I go in for my first Lymphedema treatment at 5:00 PM Eastern. The swelling in my legs has gotten worse (during the wait for an appointment) and the pitting in my calves is pretty bad when I press on my legs with a finger. The pain is also bad, but I am controlling that with 2 Extra Strength Tylenol every 4 hours to stay ahead of the pain. Due to the medical expenses I have already paid for other medical treatments for my prostate cancer, these treatments will be covered at 100%, that includes the massages, wraps, compression clothing and compression pump to help make this condition more tolerable. The Lymphedema has put a big crimp in my lifestyle which is driving me crazy as I was always a very active person performing home improvement projects and maintaining my yard. I pray to God everyday to get my life back on track from this nasty side effect.
Posts.Signature: 54 Year old Da Vinci Robotic Surgery - June 3, 2015 Positive Margin near bladder Post Op: Gleason - 9 with Metastatic Disease (lymph node involvement) Post Op PSA - 7/3/15 - < 0.05 PSA: 12/29/15 - < 0.05 6/30/16 - < 0.05 12/29/16 - <0.05 38 Salvage Radiation Treatments completed 11/12/15 6 Chemotherapy Treatments completed 09/23/2016 Hormone treatments: 4th Eligard Treatment 12/29/2016 Oncologist visit February 22, 2016 Told there is an 80% chance the cancer will return (no cure, moved to containment mode)
Posts.Title: Lymphedema after Chemotherapy Treatments for Prostate Cancer?

Posts.Content: Thank you for the warm welcome, it is nice to have other folks to speak to that are going through a similar experiences. I originally went to speak to my Urologist about erection problems in September 2014. I was given a prostate exam and a PSA test and my prostate was found to be enlarged and my PSA was a 4.1. My Urologist gave me a sample of Cialis and told me that he would like to see me again in 6 months (March 2015). When I went back to see my Urologist in March 2015 he ran another PSA test and it also came back as a 4.1 and I informed him that the Cialis did not help. At this point my Urologist set up a date for the biopsy in April 2015, the rest is explained above. After the surgery it was pretty scary to hear that the post-op biopsy revealed a much worse condition. Finding out that I was now a stage four cancer patient with metastatic disease had me real worried. Luckily my daughter graduated from the Duke School of Nursing and she is a Certified Pediatric Oncology Nurse at Children's Hospital in Washington, DC. She kept me focused and set my mind at ease over the last 7 months. She is my personal nurse and an angel, she has been and continues to oversee all of my medical care. On numerous occasions she has made recommendations of tests and procedures during this battle so I would receive nothing but the best care possible.
Posts.Title: New to the Forum

Posts.Content: I completed my 38 radiation treatments last week and had a PSA test and the results are in 0.00 We are celebrating the good news right now, however I will remain on Lupron for another 19 months as part of my original 3 tier treatment plan (Da Vinci Robotic Surgery, Hormone Therapy - Lupron and Radiation) as a precaution. I have also been told that I will being getting PSA tests every 3 months due to the fact I was diagnosed with stage 4 cancer with metastatic disease (post surgery biopsy).

Posts.Title: Newest Member of the Zero Club

Posts.Content: During my prostate cancer fight, I've had Da Vinci surgery, hormone therapy, 38 radiation treatments and 8 chemotherapy treatments. Shortly after my chemotherapy I developed Lymphedema, swelling in both feet and legs. I had no idea I was at an increased risk by having lymph nodes removed and due to both radiation and chemotherapy. Lymphedema happens when you lymphatic system does not allow the lymphatic fluid to flow properly in your body, thus causing swelling in limbs and it can take up to 36 months to occur. From everything I have read, there is no cure for Lymphedema, just treatments. Unfortunately there is no way to determine what treatment caused mine. I have an appointment on November 7th to be evaluated and a plan put in place to fight this nasty side effect. From what I have read the plans include exercises, massages of the lymph nodes, compression pumps and compression clothing to reduce swelling, thus reducing the pain. Has anyone else developed Lymphedema? If so what are you doing to combat the swelling and pain?
Posts.Signature: 54 Year old Da Vinci Robotic Surgery - June 3, 2015 Positive Margin near bladder Post Op: Gleason - 9 with Metastatic Disease (lymph node involvement) Post Op PSA - 7/3/15 - < 0.05 PSA: 12/29/15 - < 0.05 6/30/16 - < 0.05 12/29/16 - <0.05 38 Salvage Radiation Treatments completed 11/12/15 6 Chemotherapy Treatments completed 09/23/2016 Hormone treatments: 4th Eligard Treatment 12/29/2016 Oncologist visit February 22, 2016 Told there is an 80% chance the cancer will return (no cure, moved to containment mode)
Posts.Title: Lymphedema after Chemotherapy Treatments for Prostate Cancer?

Posts.Content: Good luck Mike. I had the DaVinci robotic surgery and began hormone treatment (Lupron) 30 days after surgery. They plan of keeping me on Lupron for 2 to 3 years and then monitoring my PSA levels after the hormone treatments are stopped. I am currently receiving salvage radiation treatments and will receive treatment number 23 of 38 today. I decided to use all options in an attempt to eliminate my prostate cancer. Radiation treatment side effects can be rough but you just have to be strong and remember that they will over before you know it and the benefits of the treatments far out weigh the side effects.
Posts.Title: And On It Goes

Posts.Content: Good luck Mike. I had the DaVinci robotic surgery and began hormone treatment (Lupron) 30 days after surgery. They plan of keeping me on Lupron for 2 to 3 years and then monitoring my PSA levels after the hormone treatments are stopped. Posts.Title: And On It Goes

Posts.Content: Hello all, I have been reading a lot of the posts and decided I might as well introduce myself. My name is Ron, I live in Northern Virginia and I was diagnosed with prostate cancer in April 2015. My first biopsy show 8 cores of 12 positive for cancer with a Gleason score of 7. I did some research and decided to have my prostate removed via the DaVinci Robotic Procedure. After the biopsy results were in I had a bone scan which turned out negative, an MRI with contrast which showed the cancer had broken through the prostate capsule and possibly had lympnode involvement. After I got the results I met with my Urologist Dr. John Klien and my Oncologist Dr. Joseph Lee to discuss my options. After meeting with both of them, they each recommended that I choose radiation because the odds of the surgery being successful was only 30%. My family and I met and discussed my options in great detail and I decided to stay with my original plan to have my prostate removed. When we discussed this with my Urologist he tried to push me to choosing radiation. I stood my ground and my Urologist finally agreed to perform the surgery but he wanted me to understand that I would need the salvage radiation treatments after surgery, I informed him that I fully understood this. Well my surgery took place on June 3rd and it went much longer than planned, the total surgery time was 7 1/2 hours and I almost needed a blood transfusion during surgery. After the surgery my Urologist came in to speak with my family and I and stated that the cancer had in fact engulfed one nerve bundle, the seminal vesicle and at least one lymphnode and that he removed the nerve bundle, the seminal vesicle and 11 lymphnodes. He further stated that he sent out a sample to pathology as soon as the surgery started and that those results showed a different picture. There was a positive margin just below the bladder and the post operation pathology came back with a Gleason scale of 9 and that one lymphnode tested positive for cancer Fast forward 30 days, I was placed on Lupron on July 3rd to help control the cancer. I have since been feeling the effects of the Lupron with hot flashes, chills, fatigue and loss of sex drive. My Urologist informed me that I had a maximum of four months to recover before the salvage radiation treatments would begin. I regained my continence during that time and that was a huge plus for me. My radiation treatments began in September, I was informed that there would be 38 treatments, today I receive treatment number 22. Unfortunately I have been dealing with side effects abdominal pain, increased fatigue and diarrhea from the radiation treatments. These side effects really are miserable but I just keep pushing forward knowing that I will be finished with the radiation treatments on November 12. My family and I will be celebrating on November 12th after my last treatment. I hope to be cancer free one day, God willing. I did meet with my Urologist before starting radiation treatments and asked him what he thought about the choices I made and he informed that after looking back on everything that the choices I made were in fact the best way to go, that made me feel good. Do I have any regrets about my choices? Absolutely not, I had as much of the cancer removed from my body as possible and I am attacking the cancer with a three step fight, surgery, hormone therapy and radiation treatments. Do I understand that there is a 80% to 90% chance of recurrence of the cancer? Yes I do and I will fight that battle if and when that happens.
Posts.Title: New to the Forum

Posts.Content: I have been on Lupron (hormone therapy) since July 3rd, the side effects (hot flashes, chills, reduced energy and fatigue) can be a pain, but I find them to be manageable. Everyone is different and the effects of the n vary from person to person.

Posts.Title: Numbers on the rise...input greatly appreciated.

Posts.Content: All, I watched two television shows and some videos online that mention Rick Simpson Canabis Oil. Dennis Hill a Bio-Chemist at MD Anderson Cancer Center had Prostate Cancer (Gleason - and it had metastisized. He mentions that he held off on traditional treatments (surgery, radiation and chemotherapy) to attempt using the canabis oil. He mentioned two receptors in the body CB1 and CB1 and an Antrogen receptor that the cannabis oil bonds with to attack cancer cells. Dennis Hill claims that within 6 months that the cancerous tumor was and the metatstatic lesions were cured. Is there any known truth to this cannabis oil actually attacking and killing cancer cells like they have stated? I performed a search on the Rick Simpson cannabis oil and it is only available to California residents due to drug laws and that a 30 day supply is $1,500.

Posts.Title: Had my Biopsy today

Posts.Content: Thank you everyone, I promise to be an advocate for everyone here on the forum as well as all others fighting prostate cancer while I work with Zero Cancer. I am waiting to receive the legislative information so I can read up on the funding priorities that will be discussed before the congressional panel. Prostate Cancer Research has been funded at $80,000,000 a year for the last 6 years. Zero Cancer's goal is to secure an additional $10,000,000 in funding this year, bringing the total to $90,000,000. I will also be looking into what help (financial assistance) is available to those of us in the US that may need financial assistance with cancer treatments.

Posts.Title: Zero Cancer - An end to Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: After being contacted by Zero Cancer (www.zerocancer.org) and asked to become Prostate Cancer Advocate for Congressional funding for Prostate Cancer Research for treatments and cure, I decided to embrace this amazing opportunity. I will be speaking before 70 Congressional Leaders in Washington, DC on February 28th and March 1st to discuss my prostate cancer battle and to request that they increase the funding for research and treatments. I am honored to have been selected to join the Washington, DC Metropolitan division of this organization and I am excited for my opportunity to help others in their Prostate Cancer fight. They are also doing a Zero Heroes Story on me and my Prostate Cancer Battle.

Posts.Title: Zero Cancer - An end to Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Previously, doctors have only been able to see prostate cancer, either as a tumor or at metastatic sites, when there have been enough cancer cells gathered together to make a critical mass that would show up on MRI or another form of imaging. There was no way to target prostate cancer cells specifically. Have any cancer cells escaped the prostate? This is the question that every man who has prostate cancer, and every doctor treating him, wants to answer. Now there's a way to find out without making an incision or taking another biopsy sample. It's a brand new technique, called PSMA imaging, and it uses a PET (for positron emission tomography) scanner. The technique was developed by Martin G. Pomper, M.D., Ph.D., the William R. Brody Professor of Radiology and Director of the Division of Nuclear Medicine and Molecular Imaging, and the original support to develop it came from a grant made by Patrick C. Walsh Prostate Cancer Research Fund. "This truly is individualized medicine, and we can really help patients with it," says Pomper; in fact, men with prostate cancer from around the world have flown to Johns Hopkins just to have this test done. "The results from this new radiotracer have changed how the disease is being managed in some patients. It, and others like it being used in Europe, have caught on like wildfire." At medical meetings devoted to prostate cancer, sessions are now being taught on PSMA imaging. Here's why this is such a breakthrough: Previously, doctors have only been able to see prostate cancer, either as a tumor or at metastatic sites, when there have been enough cancer cells gathered together to make a critical mass that would show up on MRI or another form of imaging. There was no way to target prostate cancer cells specifically. But what if there could be a way to make those cells light up somehow? With this in mind, Pomper figured out a way to engineer a harmless radioactive tracer that would attach itself specifically to prostate cancer cells. The tracer targets something on the surface of these cells: a molecule called PSMA, for (prostate-specific membrane antigen). "PSMA is a protein that is present in high concentrations on the surface of prostate cancer cells," Pomper says. "PET is a sensitive imaging technique that can allow us to see tumors deep within the body. PET works by detecting the radioactive molecules we made to 'tag' the prostate cancer cells specifically." Previously in Discovery, we reported that Pomper had discovered and tested the first PSMA-targeting PET agent in a clinical trial. Now he has refined this  alphabet soup alert here  into a second-generation, PSMA-targeting PET agent called DCFPyL. Pomper is excited about the potential for DCFPyL to help men throughout the prostate cancer spectrum. "This agent has vastly higher sensitivity and specificity, and it provides sharper images," he says. "That will enable us to expand the use of imaging, not only to primary disease, but to see if the disease has returned after initial treatment, to help make treatment more accurate, and even as a monitoring tool for men on active surveillance. We believe that the images we are getting are the clearest ever obtained for prostate cancer in a human being." As a bonus, because PSMA is also expressed in the blood vessels of other types of cancers, this technique may also help spot other tumors, including certain forms of kidney cancer, he adds. Pomper and colleagues recently published their results in Molecular Imaging and Biology. http://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/brady...cancer-imaging

Posts.Title: Recent Tests

PatientDecided.Sample: My name is Ron, I live in Northern Virginia and I was diagnosed with prostate cancer in April 2015. My first biopsy show 8 cores of 12 positive for cancer with a Gleason score of 7. I did some research and decided to have my prostate removed via the DaVinci Robotic Procedure....Joseph Lee to discuss my options. After meeting with both of them, they each recommended that I choose radiation because the odds of the surgery being successful was only 30%....I ended up having my prostate, the seminal vesicle, a nerve bundle and 11 lymph nodes removed, after surgery I was informed of the positive margin. Since surgery on June 3rd 2015 I have had 3 hormone therapy shots with a 4th one scheduled for the end of December, I have also had 38 radiation treatments and 8 chemotherapy treatments....Jack, I had surgery and my Gleason was a 9. My Urologist wanted me to do radiation rather than surgery but I chose not to follow that advice....My first biopsy show 8 cores of 12 positive for cancer with a Gleason score of 7. I did some research and decided to have my prostate removed via the DaVinci Robotic Procedure. After the biopsy results were in I had a bone scan which turned out negative, an MRI with contrast which showed the cancer had broken through the prostate capsule and possibly had lympnode involvement....Jack, I had surgery and my Gleason was a 9. My Urologist wanted me to do radiation rather than surgery but I chose not to follow that advice. I ended up having my prostate, the seminal vesicle, a nerve bundle and 11 lymph nodes removed, after surgery I was informed of the positive margin....After meeting with both of them, they each recommended that I choose radiation because the odds of the surgery being successful was only 30%. My family and I met and discussed my options in great detail and I decided to stay with my original plan to have my prostate removed....I completed my 38 radiation treatments last week and had a PSA test and the results are in 0.00 We are celebrating the good news right now, however I will remain on Lupron for another 19 months as part of my original 3 tier treatment plan (Da Vinci Robotic Surgery, Hormone Therapy - Lupron and Radiation) as a precaution. I have also been told that I will being getting PSA tests every 3 months due to the fact I was diagnosed with stage 4 cancer with metastatic disease (post surgery biopsy)....
